pullRequest.title: Add target constants for Anchor to use with alternate setTarget method (#8346)
pullRequest.bodyText: Implements #8346. See the issue for further discussion.

beforeCommit.message: Add target constants for Anchor to use with alternate setTarget method

afterCommit.message: Add target constants for Anchor to use with alternate setTarget method

nodes.bodyText: I would rename this API to setTarget and have it as overloaded method name. This is what we have done in other places too. The getter can then have the more specific name.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -183,4 +205,47 @@ public void setTarget(String target) { return get(targetDescriptor); } + /** + * Sets the target window, tab or frame for this anchor. The target is one of these + * special values: + *
    + *
  • AnchorTarget.DEFAULT: Removes the target value. This has the same effect as setting the target to AnchorTarget.SELF. + *
  • AnchorTarget.SELF: Opens the link in the current context. + *
  • AnchorTarget.BLANK: Opens the link in a new unnamed context. + *
  • AnchorTarget.PARENT: Opens the link in the parent context, or the + * current context if there is no parent context. + *
  • AnchorTarget.TOP: Opens the link in the top most grandparent + * context, or the current context if there is no parent context. + *
+ * + * @param target + * the target value, not null + */ + public void setTargetEnum(AnchorTarget target) {

nodes.bodyText: Since tags should be kept empty, we'll fix those once we know what release the enhancement lands into first.

nodes.bodyText: Should this just return AnchorTarget.DEFAULT when the actual string value is null instead of an optional ? I understood from the javadocs that it is semantically the same thing ?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -183,4 +205,47 @@ public void setTarget(String target) { return get(targetDescriptor); } + /** + * Sets the target window, tab or frame for this anchor. The target is one of these + * special values: + *
    + *
  • AnchorTarget.DEFAULT: Removes the target value. This has the same effect as setting the target to AnchorTarget.SELF. + *
  • AnchorTarget.SELF: Opens the link in the current context. + *
  • AnchorTarget.BLANK: Opens the link in a new unnamed context. + *
  • AnchorTarget.PARENT: Opens the link in the parent context, or the + * current context if there is no parent context. + *
  • AnchorTarget.TOP: Opens the link in the top most grandparent + * context, or the current context if there is no parent context. + *
+ * + * @param target + * the target value, not null + */ + public void setTarget(AnchorTarget target) { + Objects.requireNonNull(target, "target cannot be null."); + setTarget(target.getValue()); + } + + /** + * Gets the target window, tab or frame value for this anchor. + * + * @see #setTarget(AnchorTarget) + * + * @return an optional target, or an empty optional if no target has been + * set + */ + public Optional getTargetEnum() {

commit.message: Add target constants for Anchor to use with alternate setTarget method

nodes.bodyText:
Sorry, not done, reopening the discussion as I'm not sure if I was clear enough - I meant that instead of returning an empty optional, it would return AnchorTarget.DEFAULT so the return type would not be Optional for getTargetEnum(). Is there any other issue for this than if they user uses setTarget("foobar") which cannot be parsed to the enum ? I'm not sure if returning null would be just fine then, as wrapping the enum in Optional just feels unnecessary complication.
Now that I'm thinking this, it might make sense to even deprecate the String version of setTarget(String) and recommend using the enum one instead to avoid errors.

commit.message: yet another change to test to support setter for target object

nodes.bodyText: Non-blocking: I wonder why this is an anonymous class instead of private class here but I don't think it makes any difference

Suggested change

                 * {@link #setTarget(String)} instead.
